hook.text: That shiver down your spine when a song peaks? That's dopamine â€” the same chemical as chocolate.

hook.text: You love your favorite song partly because you've heard it before â€” familiarity breeds pleasure.

hook.text: The best part of your favorite song isn't the climax â€” it's the moment right before.

hook.text: Music has no literal meaning â€” yet it makes us feel things more deeply than most words can.

hook.text: One in 10,000 people can name any note by ear â€” without a reference pitch.

buildup.text: Perfect pitch, or absolute pitch, appears in early childhood and seems partly genetic.

discovery.text: Tonal languages like Mandarin have higher rates of perfect pitch â€” suggesting training matters too.

twist.text: Mozart and Beethoven both had it â€” but many great musicians work perfectly well without it.

climax.text: Relative pitch â€” hearing intervals between notes â€” can be trained and is more musically useful.

punchline.text: Perfect pitch is a party trick. Relative pitch is a superpower.

quiz.question: What is perfect pitch?
options: The ability to identify any musical note without a reference
Playing an instrument perfectly
Singing perfectly in tune always

hook.text: Dissonance â€” two clashing notes â€” makes your brain uncomfortable, and composers know it.

climax.text: Dissonance isn't wrong â€” it's the shadow that makes consonance feel like sunlight.

quiz.question: What makes consonant intervals sound pleasing?

hook.text: You can hear your name across a crowded room â€” and your brain does the same thing with music.

hook.text: Some people literally see colors when they hear music â€” their senses are cross-wired.

hook.text: Your brain fills in missing notes, invents melodies from noise, and hears music that isn't there.

climax.text: Music perception is partly creative â€” your brain constructs what it expects to hear.

hook.text: Most people stop exploring new music around age 33 â€” and science knows exactly why.

hook.text: That song stuck in your head? Scientists call it an earworm â€” and 98 percent of people get them.

hook.text: A song can make you remember something that never happened â€” and you'll swear it's real.
